instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.2V5_NAND: What is 2V5_NAND? This is a power rail that powers the SSD that is soldered onto the logic board of Macbook Pro models with a soldered on SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
Hello, back again with a funky one. I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no signs of liquid damage that sits at 20v 0.00a. When plugging the board into another MacBook it is instantly recognized as being in DFU mode every time it is connected. I have tried reviving and restoring multiple times and it always fails giving 1 of 2 error messages shown in the attached photos. Not sure how to proceed on this one.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.35v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 0v (looks to be told to enable by T2 which isn't sending out that signal for some reason)
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 0v (read other posts that you need this for DFU but the others have said they had a successful DFU and it restored this rail so I don't know.)

These T2 models are pretty annoying and seem to have many issues, unfortunately.

Thanks for any help you guys can provide!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
Seems to have a problem with SSD.
Check diode mode to ground on its power rails.
SSD voltages should come on during DFU process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> is ~50 ohm to ground, and known good is ~100k. Checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL> and it has a 0 ohm to ground. Looks like <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> is bad based off thermals, there is also a small bump on the chip only visible at certain angles. I think this is the issue and I should have checked for a short first, don't know why I didn't before posting. Thanks for the help and sorry for wasting your time on this thread.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message: Well, looks like that wasnt it. Short is gone but still no <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>. Will post updates later.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
" <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.35v 
-------------------------------------
Checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL> and it has a 0 ohm to ground."
How is possible to get 12.35V into 0 ohm to ground???

Did you remove power when checked resistance to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message: Yes, no power just plain board on desk. <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> had a dead short to ground, replaced it and now short is gone. Not sure how that is possible but it fixed the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still 12.35v though, and DFU has the same error.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
The mentioned rails are connected through <RESISTOR>R5460</RESISTOR>.
So you had 12V one side and short to ground on the other.
What do you think about this resistor, or its traces???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5460</RESISTOR> was not on this board and its pads look factory, I still get 12.35v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL> though but no voltage on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>. The whole area around <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> looked fine except for <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> itself. Had a slight bulge in the chip and a small burn mark right outside the chip (near pin 21 and 22). Ive noticed something weird though, [I]when heating the area around L9081, I get resistance readings similar to a working board on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>. When the board is cold, I only get ~150 ohm to ground[/I]. <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is still missing as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message: Actually, never mind on that 150 ohm reading, it's getting normal resistance now. I think it could have just been drained caps on SSD0? <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> does not get  <SIGNAL>SSD0_PMIC_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL>, looks like that comes directly from <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> and(?) <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> through <RESISTOR>R9618</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
Leakage from 12V to <SIGNAL>2V5_NAND</SIGNAL> could damaged a NAND chip (through <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>); even if you don't get low resistance there.

<RESISTOR>R5460</RESISTOR> boards have direct continuity, so I can't really understand how could you got short one side and 12V the other side.
I'm not sure about how do you measure on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
I measured the board in diode mode, black probe ground, and just the board with nothing connected. You are correct that it should not be 12v on one side and then short on the other, most reasonable explanation is I misread a reading or used the wrong pin. <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> was shorted though and was taking 1.8a at 1.5v when injecting on  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>.

Definitely a weird short like you said, but it's gone after replacing <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>. I found a document I believe you posted on the forum showing the power sequence of the rails for T2 machines so I am going to just go through those rails and see what's missing for now. Thanks for the help so far, I will update the thread with any solutions I come across.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.00a
threads.message:
Do you get now 12.3V on the same point where you've got short before (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>) ?
If not, you have broken trace; which can explain the issue about short and 12.3V on the same rail...
